articles.headline: With Fire TV, Amazon Seeks a Beachhead in the Living Room
articles.snippet: The company’s new device, called Amazon Fire TV, will marry its video library with content from other providers.
articles.abstract: The company’s new device, called Amazon Fire TV, will marry its video library with content from other providers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amazon is a retailer that makes and sells entertainment. On Wednesday, it took a big step toward a future in which shopping and video are tightly linked, perhaps even inseparable.

articles.headline: Power Surge for Donors as Terrain Is Reshaped on Campaign Money
articles.snippet: A Supreme Court decision eradicating a key campaign finance limit is expected to widen the world of high-dollar fund-raising now dominated by “super PACs” and big-spending political nonprofit groups.
articles.abstract: A Supreme Court decision eradicating a key campaign finance limit is expected to widen the world of high-dollar fund-raising now dominated by “super PACs” and big-spending political nonprofit groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: Big donors, leaders of political parties and candidates with access to wealthy supporters will be the biggest beneficiaries of the Supreme Court decision issued on Wednesday, a ruling that could fundamentally reshape the political terrain in the 2014 elections and beyond.

articles.headline: Commodity Chief Blythe Masters to Leave JPMorgan Chase
articles.snippet: The departure of the executive comes as the bank prepares to sell its physical commodities business to a Swiss trading firm for $3.5 billion.
articles.abstract: The departure of the executive comes as the bank prepares to sell its physical commodities business to a Swiss trading firm for $3.5 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:35 p.m. | A prominent executive is leaving JPMorgan Chase as her powerful trading operation has stopped performing up to expectations, underscoring that Chase, the nation’s largest bank, is not immune to the boom and bust cycles that periodically sweep through Wall Street.

articles.headline: G.M. Secrecy on Crashes Adds to Families’ Pain
articles.snippet: Relatives of people killed in accidents involving recalled General Motors cars find it hard to get information partly because of how G.M. defines victims, and the technology of “black boxes.”
articles.abstract: Relatives of people killed in accidents involving recalled General Motors cars find it hard to get information partly because of how G.M. defines victims, and the technology of “black boxes.”
articles.lead_paragraph: There is anger that General Motors did not come forward sooner with information about its faulty cars. There is grief that loved ones were lost in crashes that might have been preventable. And there is outrage that federal safety regulators did not intervene.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: Carters Return to Capital, Onstage
articles.snippet: Former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, will attend the opening of “Camp David,” a play that recounts the 13 days that led to the peace treaty between Israel and Egypt.
articles.abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, will attend the opening of “Camp David,” a play that recounts the 13 days that led to the peace treaty between Israel and Egypt.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jimmy Carter was never a creature of Washington, and so after he lost re-election in 1980 — “I was involuntarily retired,” he often says — he seldom looked back. But on Thursday night, Mr. Carter will return to the capital in the strange role of spectator to his often-maligned presidency.

articles.headline: Iraq Veteran at Fort Hood Kills 3 and Himself in Rampage
articles.snippet: The authorities said that the motive of the gunman, an Army specialist who was being treated for behavioral and mental health issues, remained unclear, but that the shooting did not appear to be related to terrorism.
articles.abstract: The authorities said that the motive of the gunman, an Army specialist who was being treated for behavioral and mental health issues, remained unclear, but that the shooting did not appear to be related to terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — A soldier who was being evaluated for post-traumatic stress disorder opened fire at Fort Hood on Wednesday, killing three people and wounding 16 before killing himself, the authorities said. The shooting set off a huge police response and shut down the sprawling Army base, the same facility where a deadly rampage by an officer resulted in 13 deaths in 2009.
articles.byline: By Dave Montgomery, Manny Fernandez and Ashley Southall

articles.headline: A Union Aims at Pittsburgh’s Biggest Employer
articles.snippet: The Service Employees International Union is trying to organize service workers at the 22 hospitals in the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center in an effort to raise their salaries.
articles.abstract: The Service Employees International Union is trying to organize service workers at the 22 hospitals in the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center in an effort to raise their salaries.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — For decades, United States Steel was this city’s dominant employer, but now the biggest employer is the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, with its 22 hospitals and 62,000 workers.

articles.headline: Fake Meats, Finally, Taste Like Chicken
articles.snippet: Demand is growing from younger consumers seeking a more healthful or more ethical diet, but innovation is pushed by investors who see a potential solution to big problems.
articles.abstract: Demand is growing from younger consumers seeking a more healthful or more ethical diet, but innovation is pushed by investors who see a potential solution to big problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last May, Whole Foods recalled two types of curried chicken salad that had been sold in some of its stores in the Northeast.

articles.headline: Criminal Inquiry Said to Be Opened on Citigroup
articles.snippet: Federal authorities have opened a criminal investigation into a recent $400 million fraud involving Citigroup’s Mexican unit, according to people briefed on the matter, one of a handful of government inquiries looming over the bank.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities have opened a criminal investigation into a recent $400 million fraud involving Citigroup’s Mexican unit, according to people briefed on the matter, one of a handful of government inquiries looming over the bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just as Citigroup was putting a troubled past of taxpayer bailouts and risky investments behind it, the bank now finds itself in the government’s cross hairs again.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Out of Work, Out of Benefits, and Running Out of Options
articles.snippet: Short-term unemployment has fallen to its prerecession level, but long-term unemployment remains more than twice as high as it was in 2007.
articles.abstract: Short-term unemployment has fallen to its prerecession level, but long-term unemployment remains more than twice as high as it was in 2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Abe Gorelick has decades of marketing experience, an extensive contact list, an Ivy League undergraduate degree, a master’s in business from the University of Chicago, ideas about how to reach consumers young and old, experience working with businesses from start-ups to huge financial firms and an upbeat, effervescent way about him. What he does not have — and has not had for the last year — is a full-time job.

articles.headline: Switching Names to Save on Taxes
articles.snippet: Caterpillar ducked billions of dollars in United States income taxes with a simple strategy. Whether it was legal is open to debate.
articles.abstract: Caterpillar ducked billions of dollars in United States income taxes with a simple strategy. Whether it was legal is open to debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Call it the banality of tax avoidance.
